channel.title: Philosophy of Mind on The Approximate Mind
channel.description: Recent content in Philosophy of Mind on The Approximate Mind

item.title: The Approximate Mind, Part 5: What Will AI Eventually Feel?
item.description:
Throughout this series, I’ve carefully skirted a question. I’ve discussed functional understanding, confidence calibration, context-awareness. But I’ve added disclaimers: “AI doesn’t have phenomenal consciousness,” “It doesn’t feel uncertainty.”

These aren’t evasions, they’re honest acknowledgments of what we don’t know. But they leave hanging the question many people actually care about:

item.title: The Approximate Mind, Part 10: What We've Learned and What Remains Unknown
item.description: This is where I’m supposed to wrap everything up. Ten articles exploring how AI approaches understanding, what it can approximate, what remains beyond reach. Time for the synthesis, the grand conclusion, the neat ending.

item.title: The Approximate Mind, Part 11: The Dichotomy of Curiosity
item.description:
What does it mean for an AI to be curious?

Not curious in the romantic sense of wondering at the stars. Not the child’s persistent “why” that drives parents to exhaustion. I mean something more specific: the computational pressure to seek information that isn’t currently possessed but might matter.
